channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Salisbury Journal: Distant British Past Is Also Present for Salisbury
item.description: Between the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta, a copy of which resides there, and summer solstice at Stonehenge, it’s big doings in Salisbury, England.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayors from Wiltshire at Salisbury Cathedral on Monday during celebrations of the 800th anniversary of the signing of Magna Carta.

item.title: E.U. Agrees to Extend Economic Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: The decision to prolong the sanctions for six months frustrated a campaign by Moscow to win a blocking vote from one of the countries in the European bloc.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: With Tourist Missing, Worry Spreads on Camino de Santiago in Spain
item.description: An American, Denise Thiem, disappeared in April along the Catholic pilgrimage, which has drawn a record number of people in recent years.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Camino de Santiago, a route in northern Spain that ends at the cathedral of Santiago de Compostela, has drawn hundreds of thousands of tourists over the last few years.

item.title: Taliban Strike Crucial District in Afghanistan
item.description: The group overran Musa Qala at least temporarily, local residents said, demonstrating the insurgents’ power in an area that American and British troops had long fought to keep out of their control.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reactions to the Defeat of the Hong Kong Election Plan
item.description: Pro-democracy campaigners cheered its failure, while supporters of the Beijing-backed proposal vowed to use the defeat to campaign against pan-democratic lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators celebrating outside the Legislative Council in Hong Kong on Thursday after it rejected a Beijing-vetted proposal on electing the city’s top official.

item.title: Pope Francis Aligns Himself With Mainstream Science on Climate
item.description: If anything, environmental scientists say, the pope may have bent over backward to offer a cautious interpretation of the scientific facts.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: An Indian boy with a bag filled with recyclable material at a garbage dump in Gauhati, India.

item.title: Pope Francis, in Sweeping Encyclical, Calls for Swift Action on Climate Change
item.description: He attributed environmental destruction to apathy, the reckless pursuit of profits, excessive faith in technology and political shortsightedness.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis was greeted by crowds at St. Peter’s Square this week.

item.title: News Analysis: In Eurozone, Growing Support for a Greek Exit
item.description: Economists and government officials in Europe have begun to accept that little more is to be gained in this struggle to get Greece to play by the rules.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: Protesters in front of the Greek Parliament in Athens on Wednesday; they were urging Greece's European and International Monetary Fund creditors to ease their terms.

item.title: Legislature in Hong Kong Rejects Beijing-Backed Election Plan
item.description: In the end, it was the pro-democracy camp that killed a proposal for direct election of the city’s top leader, citing Beijing’s limits on who could be a candidate.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Lawmakers who supported the Beijing-backed election proposal in Hong Kong after the legislation was voted down on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rare Direct Appeal to Xi Jinping Appears, Then Disappears, Online
item.description: An online video, quickly deleted from Chinese outlets, shows a woman being subdued by bystanders after she called out to President Xi Jinping’s motorcade in the southwestern province of Guizhou.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Obama’s Plan to Send Advisers to Iraq Will Fail
item.description: Keeping them holed up on “lily pads” defeats the purpose of training troops.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OWEN WEST
item.media:description: An American soldier with an Iraqi trainee at a base in Taji, Iraq.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Explaining China in Its Own (Varied) Terms
item.description: Zhang Weiwei, whose ‘‘China model’’ theory of development has influenced top leaders, employs more Confucius and statistics than Marx to explain why China under the Communist Party is certain to succeed.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman walking along the Shanghai Bund against the Pudong district skyline.

item.title: 60 Million People Fleeing Chaotic Lands, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations refugee agency finds that war and persecution have displaced a record number of people.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Syrian children crossing into Turkey this week. The U.N. says the war in Syria is the world's biggest source of displacement.

item.title: World Briefing: Kosovo: Slovenia Detains Ex-Premier
item.description: War crimes investigators in Serbia want to hold Former Prime Minister Ramush Haradinaj accountable for the killings of Serbs while he was a commander of Western-backed insurgents in the late 1990s.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: World Briefing: Plan to Train Iraqi Soldiers Is Hampered by Lack of Recruits, Defense Chief Says
item.description: The U.S. has fallen behind its goal of training 24,000 Iraqi security forces by this fall, having only trained 9,000 so far.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Hungary: Anti-Migrant Fence Proposed
item.description: The government is considering building a 13-foot-high fence along the border with Serbia to stop the flow of migrants reaching the country.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Congressional Memo: Trade Bill’s Fate Rests on What’s Been Missing in Congress: Trust
item.description: President Obama’s trade bill now hinges on a complex brew of congressional relationships, procedural rigmarole and several leaps of faith across party lines.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.title: Dominican Republic Set to Deport Haitian Migrants
item.description: Even before a Wednesday night deadline to register with the government, migrant workers have been routinely seized and expelled.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Haitians waited at the Police and Interior Ministry in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, to register to avoid deportation.

item.title: Foreign Groups Fear China Oversight Plan
item.description: A proposed law would require international organizations to find a government sponsor, seek police approval for all “activities” and hire Chinese citizens for at least half of all staff positions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A Greenpeace investigator taking a wastewater sample in China's Inner Mongolia region in 2013. Legislation would require foreign groups to be supervised.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Yemen
item.description: The bombs, which ripped through mosques in the capital Sana during prayer times, were another attempt to inflame tensions during cease-fire negotiations in Geneva.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and SAEED AL-BATATI
